comments.commentBody:
Yes, JM, but prices on all these goods change weekly.

Supermarkets can overcharge by posting ONE price in the store ("apples a dollar a pound! buy these canned beans at 79 cents each!") and then, at the register, having them scan up at a different price ("let's put in the code for apples and, hey, it's a buck fifty a pound! let's not bother to change the actual price on the beans from last week's 99 cents a can!")
Don't panic. And keep an eye on your towel.
If there was ever any doubt, this demonstates that medical marijuana is completely out of hand.
Should this really be a priority right now? Sending people to other stars? Any money involved in this could be put to better use.
This article should be titled "Offering Funds, U.S. Agency Dreams about Dreaming about Another U.S. Agency Sending Humans to Stars".

This idea is completely realistic in scientific terms. Not only could we use some sort of nuclear energy to power the way but by the time that an expedition of this sort can be made scientists may discover and understand dark energy and dark matter(both thought to make the power generated from nuclear look like burning trees for warmth). With these advances this voyage will be possible and necessary. Come on people the sun will blow up in four billion years and it will expand making life unbearable on the planer billions of years earlier. We better be gone by then!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
However politically we are screwed, no private organization will be able to foot the bill for it and current politicians care more about repaving the same road ten times then saving the future of our civilization.
This is just one more example of the waste, fraud, and corruption that characterize all government spending.

http://boingboing.net/2011/07/... - has an article on uploading human consciousness as digital constructs and Ray Kurzweil ("The Singularity is Near") predicts this will happen by 2039. Live in digital utopia on the way to the new world, download on arrival as the perfectly adapted creature for every separate world's constraints. The Galaxy is ours!
~We must look beyond the blue blanket.

This suggestion is "Looney" but then humans are "Looney" most of the time. So they want to spend fortunes to go meet their star/s when the time it will take for them to get there will take a whole lifetime that we may never hear from them again.

What we need are stars down here on earth to try figure out how we can get out of our starry eyed mess - so that the next generation can just about walk around without suffering from starvation while paying our debts. Yes, the dreamers can dream on...I'll even donate a pillow & it's all right to dream. But the time has come for getting back down to Earth & finding our feet first while staying awake. & if the stars on high could talk back, they'd say the same thing or maybe even this, "Don't even think of getting in the way of our light"! Period!
Other than to make a bundle of money, why do we want to extend the lives of unhealthy people?
OH MY!!!  What will people think of next!  We can eat our cake and have it too.

Now the cats will get obese from having no exercise in running after mice because the mice will be walking instead of running because of being fat.

Fancy that! Obese cats that won't be able to catch obese mice.

Well "kudos" to the drug company for finding yet another profitable way of "extending" the life of the obese by taking an expensive pill. What was it? Six months? I'm sure the "morbidly obese" humans and their families will appreciate their dedication to "helping". And what did this "study" cost? I'm sure if the entire psyche of our warped ideology of "keeping government out of our lives" just hired a good PR firm, we could shift the
dialogue by getting rid of the sugar, high fructose corn syrup and high fat content of most of our food IN THE FIRST PLACE. And yes, the "Government" has the best system in place, with the money and the tools to do a bit of good for "the greater good" of American society.

From a societal point of view, it would be great if a drug could prevent disease in the obese. The manufacturer would profit handsomely, society would save enormous amounts on health care costs, and obese people would not have to worry about diabetes, cancer, heart disease, and stroke ( I presume they're not anticipating prevention of arthritis, varicose veins and other physical effects of excess weight).

From a scientific point of view, I would be very surprised if, even if it worked, a drug with such dramatic effects on multiple complex physiological processes had no serious side effects.

From a common sense point of view, this is pure magical thinking: Does any sensible person really accept that a taking single drug will reverse all the consequences of a lifetime of inactivity and nutritional imbalances?

Finally (and I mean no disrespect to obese people) one must admit that there is an element of Rube Goldberg in this approach.
Oh, this sounds great. So now you can remain fat, and live longer. I sure expect this to improve the quality of fat peoples' lives, and make them, and all food companies, very happy! Duh?!

hey kids, read the article. the fares are going up to pay the bonds on capital expenses:

"The Port Authority controls many of the region’s bridges, tunnels, shipping ports and airports. It has also overseen and paid for most of the World Trade Center reconstruction project, which has siphoned off billions of dollars that would otherwise have been spent on its transportation assets."

Bond holders (that would be banks, insurance companies, funds, etc.) get theirs off the top. That is always why fares are increased, not operating expenses like salaries.

"The bigger and more perplexing question that comes to my mind every rainy day, is why someone hasn't designed an umbrella that is less complex in structure, more resilient to frequent use, and more compact for easier transportation?"

Sure. It's called a rain poncho. Mostly worn by tourists, and yet eminently more practical than an umbrella.

The first time I saw anything in miniature was a trip to Chicago and the incredible Colleen Moore castle. I immediately fell in love with all things miniature. At 12, I started collecting and it became a hobby that my Dad and I fell in love with. My Dad, a dentist, began to design and build incredibly beautiful pieces of furniture and eventually, when I bought a massive house, he did some incredible work to it. He even sold some of his pieces. With him being gone now, I have many wonderful memories of working on projects together, watching the progress of the house, etc. I have all the furniture he built, many of them with different types of wood, inlay, they are amazing.

There were many times I was teased as a kid for having a dollhouse so like others, learned to keep it quiet. Even now, people will look at me funny if it comes up until they see the house and the furniture. Then I stand back and watch them ooh and ahh like little kids.

As for the feelings of control or obsession, I guess I never thought about any of that other than just simple enjoyment. Of seeing day-to-day things made so small, its just pure fun. Nothing more than that to it.

You have ruined my day. I looked at all those pictures, and the longing in my soul for a dollhouse feels unbearable. Did you really have to write this piece? I'm in my 30's now, and one article about dollhouses is enough to push me right back into the mindset of a 7-year old who wants a dollhouse SO BADLY but knows that her parents can't afford to indulge her. Why was there no warning label on this story?

PS Can we be best friends so I can come over and play with that dollhouse? Pretty please?
Also, please let me know if there's any way in which I could be shrunk down so I can live in that beautiful dollhouse and nap on that comfy armchair.

And if you're interested, the Herman Miller Company sells a miniature version of the famous Isamu Noguchi coffee table. They also still make the big one, with the wooden support and the glass top. I have both of them. I don't collect miniatures except for car models, but I couldn't resist the little Noguchi coffee table.
Why only online resources? Don't you know about the magnificent Tiny Doll House store on the UES, 314 East 78th Street?

comments.userLocation: Metro New York on New Jersey Side of it
comments.commentBody: WOW and good for her.

I've been entranced w/ miniatures since childhood as well and adored my collection of Petite Princess furniture. My daughter had a lovely handmade dollhouse we bought for her in Maine and I well recall 1 hour trips to the dollhouse shoppe in Lancaster to find items for her house. Later on I created hundreds of miniature reproduction paintings which I sold on eBay for anywhere from $29.99 to $80 each. For a few years there until corporate ruined the experience, eBay had one of the finest miniature buying experiences you could possibly imagine. They even had a specialized group of miniature artisans. Alas Meg Whitman came along and ruined everything. You might want to look at Fingertip Fantasies as well. http://www.dollhouseminiatures.com/
